topics.title: Cold open: surprising signup experiment lift
topics.summary: Laura recounts an A/B test where adding questions to the signup flow unexpectedly increased conversion by ~5%, setting up the episode’s experimentation theme.

topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Laura (new Head of Growth at Amplitude; previously Twilio, Rapid) and previews topics: career frameworks, experimentation, growth strategy, and selling to developers.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Public.com treasury accounts and Eppo A/B testing platform.

topics.title: Laura joins: new role and Twilio tenure
topics.summary: They banter about Elena Verna’s referral, Laura’s first days at Amplitude, and her early-employee rank at Twilio.

topics.title: Career growth: limits of the traditional path
topics.summary: Laura explains why relying solely on excelling in-role and manager advocacy can be limiting, and introduces her approach: create leverage by bringing customer insights to leadership.

topics.title: Build internal brand through customer understanding
topics.summary: They discuss how consistently sharing customer learnings builds reputation and visibility, even if ideas aren’t always adopted immediately.

topics.title: Twilio example: voice-of-customer to create growth team
topics.summary: Laura describes starting a voice-of-customer digest, earning executive attention (including the CEO), and using that credibility plus allies to pitch and form Twilio’s growth team.

topics.title: More career tactics: ungate knowledge and be an SME
topics.summary: Laura advises proactively sharing what you know (customer insights or other strengths) to become a go-to subject matter expert and create cross-team opportunities.

topics.title: Experimentation story: signup questions increased conversion
topics.summary: Laura details Twilio’s contentious decision to add several signup questions and how it boosted conversion by reducing user anxiety and confirming fit—illustrating “good friction.”

topics.title: Onboarding psychology: hide scary steps like telecom
topics.summary: A later onboarding experiment showed developers were intimidated by phone-number/telecom steps; moving code-first and embedding the telecom step later improved outcomes (“pill in a hotdog”).

topics.title: Iterate vs redesign: why big rewrites often fail
topics.summary: They discuss why iterative experimentation beats full redesigns, citing high hypothesis failure rates (often 80–90%) and the value of learning quickly from small tests.

topics.title: Fail faster: cheaper validation than A/B tests
topics.summary: Laura argues A/B tests are expensive and recommends faster pre-validation methods like painted-door tests and mocks to filter ideas before engineering-heavy experiments.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Writer, an enterprise generative AI platform for on-brand content creation.

topics.title: Data vs gut: confidence thresholds in experiments
topics.summary: Laura explains being data-driven while using qualitative signals, challenges strict 95% confidence for many product experiments, and stresses pre-committing to decision rules and validation plans.
